title: Contributing to rosettaR
text: outlines propose change rosettaR. detailed discussion contributing tidyverse packages, please see development contributing guide code review principles.

title: Contributing to rosettaR
text: can fix typos, spelling mistakes, grammatical errors documentation directly using GitHub web interface, long changes made source file. generally means ’ll need edit roxygen2 comments .R, .Rd file. can find .R file generates .Rd reading comment first line.

title: Contributing to rosettaR
text: want make bigger change, ’s good idea first file issue make sure someone team agrees ’s needed. ’ve found bug, please file issue illustrates bug minimal reprex (also help write unit test, needed). See guide create great issue advice.

title: Contributing to rosettaR
text: Fork package clone onto computer. haven’t done , recommend using usethis::create_from_github("timalamenciak/rosettaR", fork = TRUE). Install development dependencies devtools::install_dev_deps(), make sure package passes R CMD check running devtools::check(). R CMD check doesn’t pass cleanly, ’s good idea ask help continuing. Create Git branch pull request (PR). recommend using usethis::pr_init("brief-description--change"). Make changes, commit git, create PR running usethis::pr_push(), following prompts browser. title PR briefly describe change. body PR contain Fixes #issue-number. user-facing changes, add bullet top NEWS.md (.e. just first header). Follow style described https://style.tidyverse.org/news.html.

title: Contributing to rosettaR
text: New code follow tidyverse style guide. can use Air apply style, please don’t restyle code nothing PR. use roxygen2, Markdown syntax, documentation. use testthat unit tests. Contributions test cases included easier accept.

title: Contributing to rosettaR
text: Please note rosettaR project released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project agree abide terms.

title: Overview
text: two variables saved package work . template-statement pair describes weight apple. Let’s declare can see inside: idea behind rosettaR one may want model knowledge contained sentence multiple ways. template-statement pair constitutes core piece information (sometimes called “semantic anchor”) can transformed multiple representations. can turn data frame: ’s pretty straightforward usage, can get complicated . can transform statement CSV, slots become column headers values go columns: ’re still pretty simple territory , let’s get little complex. original idea behind Rosetta Statements make easier create knowledge graphs RDF. example RDF graph describes weight apple: Describing exactly TTL beyond scope vignette, reading likely idea RDF/OWL/etc. let’s feed string workflow see happens:
code:
print(apple_template) #> [1] "{{ object }} has a {{ quality }} of {{ value }} {{ unit }}" print(apple_statement) #> [1] "Apple X has a weight of 241.68 grams" knitr::kable(rosetta_format(apple_statement, apple_template)) rosetta_format(apple_statement, apple_template,                 "Object,Quality,Value,Unit
                {{ object }},{{ quality }},{{ value }},{{ unit }}") #> [1] "Object,Quality,Value,Unit

               Apple X,weight,241.68,grams" apple_rdf <- '@prefix ex:    <http://example.org/instance/> . @prefix ncit:  <http://ncicb.nci.nih.gov/xml/owl/EVS/Thesaurus.owl#> . @prefix pato:  <http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/PATO_> . @prefix iao:   <http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/IAO_> . @prefix obi:   <http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OBI_> . @prefix ro:    <http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/RO_> . @prefix uo:    <http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/UO_> . @prefix rdf:   <http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#> . @prefix rdfs:  <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> . @prefix xsd:   <http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#> .  ############################################################ ## OBJECT: the particular apple ############################################################  ex:apple     rdf:type ncit:apple ;     rdfs:label "{{ object }}" ;     ro:has_quality ex:apple{{ quality }} .  ############################################################ ## QUALITY: weight of the apple ############################################################  ex:apple{{ quality }}     rdf:type pato:{{ quality }} ;                 # PATO:weight     iao:is_about ex:apple ;     iao:is_quality_measured_as ex:apple{{ quality }}Datum .  ############################################################ ## MEASUREMENT DATUM ############################################################  ex:apple{{ quality }}Datum     rdf:type iao:0000109 ;                  # IAO:scalar measurement datum     obi:has_value_specification ex:apple{{ quality }}ValueSpec .  ############################################################ ## VALUE SPECIFICATION ############################################################  ex:apple{{ quality }}ValueSpec     rdf:type obi:0001938 ;                  # OBI:scalar value specification     iao:has_measurement_value "{{ value }}"^^xsd:double ;     iao:has_measurement_unit_label uo:0000021 .  ############################################################ ## UNIT ############################################################  uo:0000021     rdf:type uo:{{ unit }} .' cat(rosetta_format(apple_statement, apple_template, apple_rdf)) @prefix ex:    <http://example.org/instance/> . @prefix ncit:  <http://ncicb.nci.nih.gov/xml/owl/EVS/Thesaurus.owl#> . @prefix pato:  <http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/PATO_> . @prefix iao:   <http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/IAO_> . @prefix obi:   <http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OBI_> . @prefix ro:    <http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/RO_> . @prefix uo:    <http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/UO_> . @prefix rdf:   <http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#> . @prefix rdfs:  <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> . @prefix xsd:   <http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#> .  ############################################################ ## OBJECT: the particular apple ############################################################  ex:apple     rdf:type ncit:apple ;     rdfs:label "Apple X" ;     ro:has_quality ex:appleweight .  ############################################################ ## QUALITY: weight of the apple ############################################################  ex:appleweight     rdf:type pato:weight ;                 # PATO:weight     iao:is_about ex:apple ;     iao:is_quality_measured_as ex:appleweightDatum .  ############################################################ ## MEASUREMENT DATUM ############################################################  ex:appleweightDatum     rdf:type iao:0000109 ;                  # IAO:scalar measurement datum     obi:has_value_specification ex:appleweightValueSpec .  ############################################################ ## VALUE SPECIFICATION ############################################################  ex:appleweightValueSpec     rdf:type obi:0001938 ;                  # OBI:scalar value specification     iao:has_measurement_value "241.68"^^xsd:double ;     iao:has_measurement_unit_label uo:0000021 .  ############################################################ ## UNIT ############################################################  uo:0000021     rdf:type uo:grams .

title: Overview
text: single statement fairly trivial. real power Rosetta Statements comes lot statements using multiple templates. order make work, needs library templates. “library” simple data frame, specific headers. built command creates one (loads one properly formatted CSV) Now let’s load real set templates included example using init_library() function. function verifies template file formatted properly: Next, let’s load statements. Note just plain text strings: can now use rosetta_match() function. “router” function automatically iterates statements, finds matching template library, extracts data. Unlike simple rosetta_format returns wide dataframe (columns variables), rosetta_match returns Long Dataframe (Entity-Attribute-Value). ensures don’t get “sparse matrix” full NAs mixing different templates. output structure ideal building knowledge graphs, every row corresponds single semantic fact (Subject-Predicate-Object).
code: # Create an empty library empty_lib <- init_library() knitr::kable(empty_lib) templates <- init_library(system.file("extdata/apple_templates.csv",                                        package="rosettaR")) knitr::kable(templates) statements <- read.csv(system.file("extdata/apple_statements.csv",                                     package="rosettaR")) head(statements) #>   TemplateID                                              statement #> 1          1                   Apple X has a weight of 2332.4 grams #> 2          1                       Apple Y has a weight of 23 stone #> 3          2           Apple X was grown in Germany and picked 2025 #> 4          2 Apple Y was grown in Canada and picked January 4, 2025 #> 5          3         Apple X has the effect of making a human happy #> 6          3        Apple Y has the effect of making a human sleepy results <- rosetta_match(statements, templates) knitr::kable(head(results, 10))

title: Overview
text: Real-world data rarely clean “Apple 1 weight 100 g”. Often, statements include optional details citations. rosettaR supports advanced template syntax handle cases.

title: Overview
text: can mark parts template optional enclosing square brackets [...]. text inside brackets missing statement, parser simply skip (return empty values slots) rather throwing error.
code: # Template with optional 'region' block tmpl <- "{{ city }} is located in {{ country }} [in the region of {{ region }}]"  # Statement WITH region s1 <- "Kitchener is located in Canada in the region of Waterloo" knitr::kable(rosetta_format(s1, tmpl)) # Statement WITHOUT region s2 <- "Kitchener is located in Canada" knitr::kable(rosetta_format(s2, tmpl))

title: Overview
text: key requirement scientific knowledge graphs attribution. can include citation logic directly templates. makes explicit statement associated source.
code: # Template explicitly asking for a DOI cited_tmpl <- "{{ city }} is in {{ country }} according to {{ doi }}"  # Input statement stmt <- "Kitchener is in Canada according to 10.123/example"  # Result captures both the fact AND the source knitr::kable(rosetta_format(stmt, cited_tmpl))

title: Overview
text: Extracting data half battle; also need ensure valid. rosettaR integrates LinkML (via Python) validate extracted data schema. ensures, example, extracted “Age” actually number, “Country” matches specific list allowed terms.

title: Overview
text: LinkML schemas defined YAML. simple example schema Apple data:
code: schema_yaml <- " id: [https://example.org/apple-schema](https://example.org/apple-schema) name: AppleSchema imports:   - linkml:types default_range: string  classes:   AppleObservation:     attributes:       object:         required: true       value:         range: float  # Value must be a number!       unit:         range: string " # Save to a temporary file for this example schema_file <- tempfile(fileext = ".yaml") writeLines(schema_yaml, schema_file)

title: Overview
text: can take output rosetta_format check schema. validation step acts powerful gatekeeper, ensuring high-quality, structured data enters final knowledge graph. # construction - much come! : Add slot validation functionality Document multiple template/statement pairs template library functionality Fix regex Rosetta_format Fix rosetta_match function
code: # 1. Good Data good_data <- data.frame(object = "Apple A", value = 150.5, unit = "g") res_good <- rosetta_validate(good_data,                               schema_file,                               target_class = "AppleObservation") print(paste("Good Data is Valid:", res_good$ok))  # 2. Bad Data (Value is a string 'Heavy', not a float) bad_data <- data.frame(object = "Apple B", value = "Heavy", unit = "g") res_bad <- rosetta_validate(bad_data,                              schema_file,                              target_class = "AppleObservation")  print(paste("Bad Data is Valid:", res_bad$ok)) if (!res_bad$ok) {   print(res_bad$issues) }

what: Turn Plain Language Statements Into RDF, CSV, or Anything
title: Turn Plain Language Statements Into RDF, CSV, or Anything
text: goal rosettaR provide series tools work Rosetta Statements, plain language statements can converted semantic data paired template.

title: Turn Plain Language Statements Into RDF, CSV, or Anything
text: can install development version rosettaR GitHub :
code: # install.packages("pak") pak::pak("timalamenciak/rosettaR")

title: Turn Plain Language Statements Into RDF, CSV, or Anything
text: basic example rosettaR can convert data:
code: library(rosettaR) statement <- "Kitchener is located in Canada" in_template <- "{{ city }} is located in {{ country }}" out_template <- "CITY,COUNTRY,,{{ city }},{{ country }}" df <- rosetta_format(statement, in_template, out_template)

title: Turn Plain Language Statements Into RDF, CSV, or Anything
text: early version package. based idea Rosetta Statements described Rosetta Statements: Simplifying FAIR Knowledge Graph Construction User-Centered Approach Lars Vogt et al.

title: Turn Plain Language Statements Into RDF, CSV, or Anything
text: Build slot restrictions template validation workflow. Implement slot restrictions validation using LinkML (major). Debug rework Shiny interface (major). Implement support optional slots. Add documentation working multiple template-statement pairs. Enhance Apple example use proper RDF, add data formats. Design hexagon logo rosettaR. Submit rosettaR CRAN. Submit rosettaR rOpenSci peer review.

title: Change a data frame into a series of statements based on templates. — df_to_statements
text: df data frame headers match slots template. dataframe must one column called "TemplateID" contains ID template used interpret row. templates Rosetta Statement template library created initLibrary function.

title: Change a data frame into a series of statements based on templates. — df_to_statements
text: data frame statement library containing statements associated templates.

title: Change a data frame into a series of statements based on templates. — df_to_statements
code: templates <- init_library() templates <- add_template(templates, apple_template) df <- data.frame(object = "Apple X",                               quality = "weight", value="100.2",                              unit="grams", TemplateID = "1") statements <- df_to_statements(df,templates)

code: init_library(file = NA)

title: Load a set of Rosetta templates into a dataframe. — init_library
text: file CSV headers 'TemplateID' 'templateText'. Headers case-sensitive required. functions like df_to_statements() add_template() expect data frame format created function.

title: Load a set of Rosetta templates into a dataframe. — init_library
text: dataframe containing either loaded templates proper headers use functions.

code: #Initialize an empty library templates <- init_library()  #Load a CSV library apple_templates <- init_library(system.file("extdata", "apple_templates.csv",  package="rosettaR"))

title: Parse a Rosetta Statement — rosetta_format
text: Converts plain language statement structured dataframe using template. Supports variables {{ var }} optional blocks [ ... ].

title: Parse a Rosetta Statement — rosetta_format
code: rosetta_format(s, in_template, out_template = "df")

title: Parse a Rosetta Statement — rosetta_format
text: s input statement string. in_template Rosetta template string. out_template output format ('df' dataframe, 'rdf' generic Turtle, Jinja string).

title: Parse a Rosetta Statement — rosetta_format
text: Either data frame out_template values filled statement in_template.

title: Parse a Rosetta Statement — rosetta_format
code: # example code rosetta_format("Apple X weighs 235 grams", "{{ fruit }} weighs {{ value }} {{ unit}}") #>     fruit value  unit #> 1 Apple X   235 grams

what: Match Multiple Statements Against a Template Library — rosetta_match
title: Match Multiple Statements Against a Template Library — rosetta_match
text: Iterates vector statements attempts match library templates. Returns long-format dataframe.

title: Match Multiple Statements Against a Template Library — rosetta_match
code: rosetta_match(statements, templates)

title: Match Multiple Statements Against a Template Library — rosetta_match
text: statements character vector plain language statements, dataframe containing column statements. templates dataframe created init_library(), containing 'TemplateID' 'templateText' columns.

title: Match Multiple Statements Against a Template Library — rosetta_match
text: data.frame long format columns: statement_id, statement_text, template_id, variable, value.

title: Match Multiple Statements Against a Template Library — rosetta_match
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{    # Vector Input    statements <- c("Kitchener is in Canada", "Paris is in France")     # Dataframe Input (e.g. from read.csv)    # df <- read.csv("my_statements.csv")     templates <- init_library(system.file("extdata/apple_templates.csv",     package="rosettaR"))    results <- rosetta_match(statements, templates) } # }

what: Batch Convert Statements to RSO RDF — rosetta_triplify
title: Batch Convert Statements to RSO RDF — rosetta_triplify
text: Converts list statements single, cohesive Turtle (TTL) string using Rosetta Statement Ontology (RSO). Handles prefix management automatically.

title: Batch Convert Statements to RSO RDF — rosetta_triplify
code: rosetta_triplify(statements, templates)

title: Batch Convert Statements to RSO RDF — rosetta_triplify
text: statements character vector plain language statements. templates dataframe created init_library().

title: Batch Convert Statements to RSO RDF — rosetta_triplify
text: single character string containing full RDF document.

title: Batch Convert Statements to RSO RDF — rosetta_triplify
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{   # (Use the same setup as above)   ttl <- rosetta_triplify(statements, templates)   cat(ttl) } # }

what: Validate a data frame against a LinkML schema — rosetta_validate
title: Validate a data frame against a LinkML schema — rosetta_validate
text: Validate data frame LinkML schema

title: Validate a data frame against a LinkML schema — rosetta_validate
code: rosetta_validate(data, schema, target_class = NULL)

title: Validate a data frame against a LinkML schema — rosetta_validate
text: data data frame (e.g. rosetta_format) list. schema Path LinkML schema YAML file. target_class class schema validate .

title: Validate a data frame against a LinkML schema — rosetta_validate
text: list containing ok (boolean) issues (list errors).

title: Validate a data frame against a LinkML schema — rosetta_validate
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{   # Create a YAML schema for this example.   schema_yaml <- "id: https://example.org/apple-schema   name: AppleSchema    imports:    - linkml:types    default_range: string  classes:    AppleObservation:     attributes:       object:         required: true       value:         range: float  # Value must be a number!       unit:         range: string"  # Save to a temporary file for this example schema_file <- tempfile(fileext = ".yaml") writeLines(schema_yaml, schema_file)# (Use the same setup as above)  good_data <- data.frame(object = "Apple A", value = 150.5, unit = "g") res_good <- rosetta_validate(good_data, schema_file,   target_class = "AppleObservation") print(paste("Good Data is Valid:", res_good$ok)) } # }
